content: The omnibus appropriations resolution for FY2003 (H.J.Res. 2) was signed into law as P.L. 108-7 on February 20, 2003. It provided funding for Interior and related agencies, as well as 10 other regular appropriations bills not enacted for FY2003. The final FY2003 appropriation included $19.08 billion for the Interior and related agencies, along with $825.0 million to repay transferred amounts for fire fighting in FY2002. Additionally, a 0.65% across-the-board cut was implemented. The bill covers agencies and programs in four federal departments, excluding the Bureau of Reclamation, and funds some agencies or programs in three other departments. The omnibus appropriations resolution for FY2003 (H.J.Res. 2) was signed into law as P.L. 108-7 on February 20, 2003, providing funding for Interior and related agencies, as well as 10 other regular appropriations bills not enacted for FY2003. President Bush submitted his FY2003 budget to Congress on February 4th, 2002, requesting $18.94 billion for Interior and related agencies, a decrease of $219.7 million from the previous year. The budget included allocations for agencies within DOI, such as $2.36 billion for the National Park Service, $2.25 billion for the Bureau of Indian Affairs, and $1.83 billion for the Bureau of Land Management. Other related agencies received funding as well, including $3.95 billion for the Forest Service and $2.82 billion for the Indian Health Service. The FY2003 budget requested funding for various agencies, including $3.95 billion for the Forest Service, $2.82 billion for the Indian Health Service, and $1.72 billion for Energy programs. Other agencies like the Smithsonian Institution and the National Endowment for the Humanities also received funding. The FY2003 budget did not include amounts for President Bush's proposal to shift federal employee pensions and health benefits costs to agencies. Increases were proposed for agencies like the Indian Health Service, Bureau of Indian Affairs, and Minerals Management Service. The FY2003 budget proposed changes in agencies' budgets, with increases for Indian Health Service, Bureau of Indian Affairs, Minerals Management Service, Smithsonian Institution, and U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service. Decreases were proposed for Forest Service, Department of Energy, U.S. Geological Survey, Bureau of Land Management, Office of Surface Mining Reclamation and Enforcement, and National Park Service. Hearings on the FY2003 budget for Interior and related agencies began on February 27th, 2002. The House Appropriations Interior Subcommittee discussed various topics including conservation initiatives, Indian trust funds, National Park Service backlog, Everglades restoration, energy programs, land use planning, wildland fire management, homeland security, and assistance to territories and freely associated states. Members also questioned proposed cuts to the U.S. Geological Survey and the transfer of its toxic substances program to the National Science Foundation, as well as workforce restructuring and privatizing jobs. The Minerals Management Service (MMS) administers two programs: the Offshore Minerals Management (OMM) Program and the Minerals Revenue Management (MRM) Program. OMM oversees leasing on outer continental shelf lands and production of offshore minerals, while MRM collects and disburses revenues from federal leases.
